questions.question_text:
An engineer creates a set of rules in a Device Group (Panorama) to permit traffic to various services for a specific LDAP user group.

What needs to be configured to ensure Panorama can retrieve user and group information for use in these rules?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is correct

Selected Answer: C
C, Master Device

I think this is another tricky question. It asks "...configured to ensure PANORAMA can retrieve user and group info...".
If the answer is what is best practice for the FIREWALLS to apply the Security rules then the answer would be C, so the Master Device can redistribute user mapping info.
But since it is for the Panorama, I think it needs the LDAP server info, so I am going with Answer B.

comments.content: so, what will the panorama use such information for? since it says it is for policy use.

comments.content: To expand my vote, if there wouldn't be source address translation we'd have two issues... 1. reply from server would be directly to the client and not through the firewall which is asymmetry 2. Client would reject server's response since source address of the response would be web server's private ip address and not the public address. Clients usually reject responses from source address which were not destination address in their request.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
U-NAT for the same zone requires source address translation as well.
Lol - Both of these devices are on the same L2 segment. The traffic between these devices would not go above the switch. But I guess D is correct.

comments.content: Actually no - The switch does not know this is going to the NATted address yet so it would forward it out to the FW.

comments.content: You are correct - Dynamic Address Groups (B) are not typically configured in a template, as they usually relate to policy settings which are defined in device groups. Antivirus Profile (D) is also related to policies and is typically configured in a device group rather than a template.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ACE
The correct answer is- ACE in my opinion.

A. Service route is configured under Templates/Device in Panorama->Setup->Services->Global- Service Route Configuration.

B. Dynamic Address Gropus is not correct. Its Under Objects

C. NTP Server Address is also configured under Setup-> Device-> Services-Global 

D. Antivurus Profile is configured in Objects-> Security Profiles- Antivirus 

E. Authentication Profile is configured under Templates/Device in Panorama-> Setup-Authentication Profile. 

Please let me know if Im wrong

Selected Answer: ACE
A, C and E correct

Selected Answer: ACE
ACE is correct.

ACE
like stated, the other are done in the Device group settings.
ACE is the correct answer. Dynamic Address Groups and Antivirus Profile are under the 'Objects' tab which belongs to Device Group.

questions.question_text:
An engineer is configuring a template in Panorama which will contain settings that need to be applied to all firewalls in production.

Which three parts of a template an engineer can configure? (Choose three.)

A firewall engineer reviews the PAN-OS GlobalProtect application and sees that it implicitly uses web-browsing and depends on SSL.

When creating a new rule, what is needed to allow the application to resolve dependencies?

choices.B: SSL and web-browsing must both be explicitly allowed.
choices.C: Add SSL and web-browsing applications to the same rule.
choices.A: Add SSL application to the same rule.
choices.D: Add web-browsing application to the same rule.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A. Tested this in the lab. SSL is the only additional app needed to be added. It appears in "depends on" when adding global protect to the rule. web-browsing doesnt need to be added because it's already implicitly allowed by allowing global protect.

Selected Answer: D
Depends on Applications:
ssl
Implicit use Applications:
web-browsing

So when I put web browsing, ssl should be implicitly allowed

Selected Answer: A
it asks to "resolve dependencies" for a new rule we can add both to make it clear but questions is just about the make it work.
must be C because the question says "When creating a new rule," not already created.

Selected Answer: A
Answer is A

comments.content: So in this example, SSL is depends on type of app for GP and it needs to be added to the same rule.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Application that is implicitly allowed while using some other application means that it is used even if you don't explicitly allow it in the rule. In this example, web-browsing is implicitly used, meaning GlobalProtect will use it and it will be allowed even if you don't explicitly allow web-browsing. On the other hand, depends on means that whatever other app GlobalProtect depends on (not implicitly allowed) needs to be explicitly allowed by the administrator in order for GlobalProtect to work and not break.

Selected Answer: A
https://applipedia.paloaltonetworks.com/
Search for different applications and their implicit and dependency on others
 Reference
GlobalProtect Google Yahoo!
Depends on Applications:
ssl
Implicit use Applications:
web-browsing

Selected Answer: D
I think it is D, Global Protect is implicitly allowing SSL already.

Selected Answer: A
A, correct, based on the Live link you shared by mercysayno765. (i know this uses facebook as an example) Reason:
>) 'Depends on' has the following applications listed: facebook-base, facebook-apps and facebook-chat. This means that in order for this to work, one or more of the these applications need to be allowed in the same rule. << Our answer, we need SSL in that same rule

'Implicitly Uses' has web-browsing listed. This means that if you allow facebook-posting, that it will also be allowing the web-browsing application implicitly.. In our case, we dont know which APP the question referes too but 'Implicitly means already uses HTTP.

Selected Answer: B
B, because that's what I would do in the real world... allow services an app uses so it works.

Selected Answer: A
https://knowledgebase.paloaltonetworks.com/KCSArticleDetail?id=kA10g000000ClV0CAK

This is by far the most confusing answer section ever created. The docs say that if you allow an app, some dependencies will be implicitly allowed. If you are making a brand new rule, you would need to allow web-browsing and allow SSL, C seems like the right answer.
